numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I look at the graph.
2. The graph shows legacy applicants.
3. For legacy applicants, the acceptance likelihood for applicants with a family-income rank above the 50th percentile stays about 2.5 times or more.
4. I notice non-legacy applicants.
5. For non-legacy applicants with a family-income rank of about the 85th percentile, the acceptance likelihood is below 1 time.
6. The acceptance likelihood is the likelihood to be accepted into an elite college.
7. I analyze the graph.
8. I wonder how these admissions numbers will change in the next several years.
9. A Supreme Court case happened in June.
10. The Supreme Court case eliminated affirmative action in college admissions.
11. The Supreme Court case eliminated affirmative action on the grounds of race.
12. I am curious about how this change will extend to legacy status.
13. Legacies are not necessarily disadvantaged.
14. Non-legacies may be disadvantaged.
15. Legacy admissions may rise.
16. Legacy admissions may drop.
17. This graph does not affect my immediate community very much.
18. I do not know anyone who aims to be accepted into a highly selective college.
19. I live near Rice University.
20. Rice University is a very selective college.
21. Rice University likely shows admissions bias.
22. The admissions bias may depend on whether an applicant is a legacy.
23. The admissions bias may depend on the income bracket of an applicant.
24. A headline captures the main idea of the graph.
25. The headline is "Application Distortion: Legacies vs. Everyone Else".
